title: Member Lecture: Among Friends and Rivals—Caravaggio in Rome (Sept 14)
title_display: Member Lecture: Among Friends and Rivals—Caravaggio in Rome
hero_caption: Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio. The Cardsharps, about 1595. Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth, Texas.
short_description: Join curatorial associate Jena K. Carvana for a discussion of the exhibition Among Friends and Rivals: Caravaggio in Rome.
list_description: Join curatorial associate Jena K. Carvana for a discussion of the exhibition Among Friends and Rivals: Caravaggio in Rome.
description:
Join curatorial associate Jena K. Carvana for a discussion of the exhibition Among Friends and Rivals: Caravaggio in Rome.

Known for his dramatic lighting effects and novel interpretations of well-known subjects, Caravaggio pioneered an original painting style that attracted powerful patrons and followers in Italy and abroad. This lecture follows the course of Caravaggio's career in Rome, as the the artist created a name for himself with both his larger-than-life personality and his artistic achievements. 

About the Speaker

Jena K. Carvana is the curatorial associate in the department of Painting and Sculpture of Europe, where she has provided research support for Among Friends and Rivals: Caravaggio in Rome (2023), Van Gogh and the Avant-Garde: The Modern Landscape (2023) and El Greco: Ambition and Defiance (2020). She received a master's degree in medieval history from the University of Leeds. Before joining the Art Institute, she held collection and curatorial internships at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago; Royal Armories, Leeds; and the Museum of Science and Industry, Chicago.

Please note that this is an in-person event that takes place at the museum. In accordance with state and City of Chicago guidelines, visitors to the museum are no longer required to wear masks or provide proof of vaccination, though anyone who would like to wear a mask is encouraged to do so. If you are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms or have been exposed to COVID-19 in the week before your visit, we ask that you stay home. We appreciate your help in keeping the museum a healthy and safe place for our staff and visitors. Learn more about our visiting policies.
